commentBody: Wow. Just wow. I thought this one would be a DNF and break my brain, but suddenly the wormhole theme kicked in and I could not believe that I finally figured it out.  I had to wait for Caitlin to explain that each of the wormhole words is a kind of ‘worm.’  I am totally in awe. What started as a frustrating experience ended with a huge self back pat!  Thank you, Dylan, for taking my brain on a wild ride through space and time ☺️
Cool puzzle!
OK this was a wild one
That was fun!
Blech, hated it, more brain power than I wanted to spend on a puzzle.
Interlocking bookworms, inchworms, and earworms? Wow! Next level construction. Great puzzle!

I couldn’t believe it when I un[EARTH]e crafted with this puzzle! 

Bravo to Mr Schiff and th[EARTH]ed the theme!

Who doesn’t love a puzzle that makes them feel smart? There I was, having passed by the revealer, and rootling around with what exactly the OPEN BOOK TEST was doing.
Says I to self, “oh it’s a kind of WORM HOLE”.  And voilà!

More rootling as I realized an EARTH worm would not work.

Now to find out if EMU OIL is used externally (yuck?) or internally (double yuck?)

Adding this brilliant puzzle to my list!
WOW. Just wow.
I'm just gobsmacked, in a good way. Love the twist(s).
Oodles of fun! Great puzzle!
I hated it. Which means I loved it and would do it again.
This one was amazing!

The complexity involved in creating this masterpiece is mindboggling. We should prostrate ourselves before the constructor, saying "We are not worthy."

I see the early birds got the worm; I hope later arrivals do too. 

Bravo, Dylan!
Mind blown!

These are SO hard for me. So I cheated. The rest was so much fun. I loved the fill. But figuring out it’s a rebus and having endings be in different answers was at times frustrating. Hence, the cheating. I will never understand a wormhole no matter how many small words are used to explain it. STEM is not my jam. Still, I love a Sunday puzzle! Thanks!!
Extremely satisfying Sunday puzzle. Feel like I could run through a brick wall right now. Not to be overly dramatic.
This was a fun one!
This broke my brain. Kudos to everyone who figured it out without help!
Amazed that I eventually caught on without going to Gameplay. And I do mean eventually. A bit proud of myself actually. Had to figure out what a wormhole was, and then it dawned. Great fun!
This one was too difficult for me. Too many directions. Even the theme of wormholes didn’t enlighten me.
Shocked when I finished it without the dreaded pop-up. Still not even sure what the theme was or how it worked.

Ok I have to comment on this one.  On my first pass I had so little filled out that I was sure I’ll need help on this one.  I figured the circles were rebuses but it was still not making sense.  Until I got to 69A and had the aha moment.  Then it was trying to match up the colored circles on my iPad mini screen, which is a bit of a pain as the color changes if it is highlighted…but I got there with not too much trouble, and then going back and forth through the wormholes!  Thankfully there were not too many obscure clues to make up for the tricksy theme.  I can’t even begin to imagine how this would be constructed - just happy to have figured it out with no lookups and just slightly over my average solve time.  Thanks to the constructor for a fun ride!

I filled in the holes last, then saw the worm theme. Thank goodness the rest of the clues were not too obscure.
More satisfying after seeing where the rest of the answers came out! I enjoy these sorts of puzzles, but I understand ymmv.

I picked up on the first layer of theming, but as always the rebuses never occur to me until I'm all flustered. Not until after I filled it did the second layer of theming kick in. I'm impressed by the construction and despite some frustration, I enjoyed it!
Oh wow. I'm inordinately proud of myself right now. SO MUCH FUN to persist and succeed without help. Bravo and much gratitude, Dylan! Brilliant concept and construction.
LOVEEEE when puzzles do this! Such a unique and fun one!

Wow! If I loved this puzzle any more, I’d have to be twins! An absolute gem—right up there with the legendary November 5, 1996 Schrödinger puzzle, and that is my highest praise. The moment I cracked the trick, it unlocked new pathways, adding even more joy to the solve. Thank you, Dylan! It was happy solving indeed!
Such fun! Tricky, but not frustrating. Best Sunday puzzle in ages!
Clever!!!!!

Nice work! Very fun to solve! 

One constructive tip: Some reference to Einstein, Hawking or Star Trek to connect it all.
I came to the comments to see what the consensus was on loving vs. hating. I didn’t even realize until then that the rebuses were types of worms. Amazing! Loved it.

Welcome to ROOTLE !

The new game where you unscramble words with your prehensile snout!




Sorry
I know it s not right?

I just couldn't muzzle myself.

[sniff, sniff]
Great puzzle!
This puzzle is not so much "highly theoretical" as "mighty incoherent."

Picked up the wormhole clue, but it took me far longer than I liked to realize the wormholes themselves were rebuses.

Great puzzle!

Hmmm. Kinda liked it, kinda didn't. Enjoyed the fill rather more than the theme, which (though clever and inventive) got a bit wearing for me after a while. 

I think Caitlin is not quite right about the wormhole mouths meeting if you fold the grid in half---they meet if you rotate the puzzle 180 degrees (it has that rotational symmetry) and then lay it on top of itself. Then the SOLUTIONS are "folded in half"---they scoot through the wormhole and then track back parallel to themselves in the other layer.

The centre very nearly finished me off. 51D unknown, 56D and 57D opaque, and the crossing 55A, E___L, frustratingly on the tip of my brain for a ridiculously long time before EXTOL jumped into focus, 56D and 57D made sense, and 51D was, well, solved.

TIL the SHAKA hand gesture. Seems to have nothing to do with Shaka Zulu, which was my first guess.

I had such fun working out the trick of the theme and solving this puzzle!   Plus I'm still chuckling at  [flat-headed crew driver].   
Thank you Dylan Schiff for a great crossword!  
It was a nice ESCAPE-ARONI  of an evening....
Boo.

Lots of fun—enjoyed it very much.  Some recent Sunday puzzles have seemed too satisfied with their own cleverness—this was not the case here.  Once you realize the worm hole meanings, it’s an enjoyable romp.

Wow, wow, wow. What a tremendous workout. I enjoyed every bit of the journey from "what in the world" to "oh, I see." I played it by ear, inched along, and finally booked a completion. Thank you, Mr. Schiff -- this was clever and great fun.

Wow wow wow. I’m predicting a lot of haters as the day goes on but I ATE it up. This was an absolute tour de force, positively next level puzzle construction. Four way rebuses, complex entries, great fill and symmetrical worm holes—out of this galaxy!

I got thru this by using reveal square and reveal word but mostly it revealed  my (possible) cognitive decline.  😉  But not to worry, most of the fill was easy so a good Sunday puzzle for two skill levels.
I really enjoyed this one, working out the theme was such a satisfying aha moment
Haters gonna hate, but I totally dug this.
Yikes!  Tempted to cheat but didn't.  Sometimes the cleverness is annoying, but this was a true challenge and I HAD TO FINISH IT.

Interesting solve. Got most of the fill without getting the theme. Some theme entries had both ends make recognizable words while others were gibberish, and none solved to the clue. Waited for the theme to emerge. Filled all squares except the colored ones. Stared at them, thought about “wormholes” and then noticed the connection between the paired entries. Filled the colored squares quickly. Corrected a couple of entries to line up with the correct theme answers. And voila! Quite the feat of construction. Needed the column to get the bonus of “-worm” connection for each theme entry. Marvelous!!

Impressive, but blew out my average time by 50%; whether that was an inherent failing, the result of doing a rebus puzzle on my phone, or just that second whiskey sour at the airport bar, I take full responsibility. Great fun!
Really well done Was filling in answers but took a while to understood what I had. Appreciate the intricacy. Bravo. Heading to your others.
Hated it.
Well done, Dylan! Fun theme and very impressive construction!

So satisfying! 
The theme makes me think of Wally the Wordworm, one of my favorite childhood books. Wally loves delicious words, and this puzzle was full of them!

This puzzle has wormed its way into my heart. Glad there were no tapeworms or ringworms in this puzzle, let alone the parasitical kind that lodged in RFK Jr.'s brain.  Very lively puzzle and on my list for POY.

Speaking of which: now that we're nearing the midway point of the year (already??), please remember to make a note somewhere of your favorite puzzles. We had a good turnout in the vote for POYs and hope that continues.

Two quotations re worms. The first is by Willam Blake, among his aphorisms, often accompanied by small woodcuts:

The cut worm forgives the plow.

This second is from late in Hamlet, Act 4 Scene 3. Claudius is seeking the whereabouts of Polonius (the two of them were in cahoots), whom Hamlet has unknowingly killed.

King: Now, Hamlet, where's Polonius?

Hamlet: At supper.

King: At supper! where?

Hamlet: Not where he eats, but where he is eaten: a certain convocation of politic worms are e'en at him. Your worm is your only emperor for diet: we fat all creatures else to fat us, and we fat ourselves for maggots: your fat king and your lean beggar is but variable service, two dishes, but to one table: that's the end.

King: Alas, alas!

Hamlet: A man may fish with the worm that hath eat of a king, and eat of the fish that hath fed of that worm.

King: What dost you mean by this?

Hamlet: Nothing but to show you how a king may go a progress through the guts of a beggar.

I absolutely loved this one. Didn't need to look a single thing up; was challenging without verging into frustrating; and the "aha!" moment for the theme, rebus, etc was so satisfying and clever. This was a journey. (And I somehow beat my average time on this one. ) Looking forward to more!

Ouch. Could just howl at missing a cue here and there - lots of good fill - and well worth the head shaking and futile attempts to escape out of those six silent, mesmerizing blanks. Boy howdy, Dylan Schiff was most assuredly IN CHARGE. I'm too worn out to even think of a riff, but it's a good kind of tired. 

Get ready for REBUS AIRLINES - now boarding angry solvers. 

Not me - every puzzle's a chance to give thanks for brain cells, vinyl floors, air, and ricearoni! PLUS - no OREOS! Woo-ie!

Can't recall the last time one hour and thirty-three minutes left this solver calling calf rope and filling in those dark empty worm holes with "reveal square". So close, said the shore to the tide - but still no purchase.

That smarts, but not as much as being just two letters off the grid proper! Two. GAH and a pox on all worm holes.

Scraped and clawed till it was ALL THERE except for the shouting - heck, I'll take a blue star for a fun challenge like this one!

Well, there was some shouting, but nothing to share in your polite company. Most was directed at operator error - can only hope that for the majority of disgruntled AIR REBUS passengers, they might temper their ire with understanding - better to be in the rarified world of rebus turbulence than rootling for everyday solves in some local penny press.

Even more fed up with the glitches in comments than ever. Talk about worms.  Yesterday (Friday) I received notice that a comment I posted last Monday was approved. About 15 minutes ago, I commented on this puzzle, and it was "approved," but has not appeared on any platform. Maybe it's gone into a wormhole and will appear in a week commenting on an LA Times puzzle! 

For all the money puzzlers shell out for access to the games you'd think they could take our comments on the problems here seriously and actually do something about it.
Nice. No notes.

This was plodding and painful for me. Took almost double time. I figured out the theme word pretty early, but it doesn’t translate well to an iPhone screen and I had a terrible time trying to switch among rebuses.
ROOTLE!?!??!!! How DARE you!
I liked it. Well done avoiding intersections of ultra-niche trivia. That's rare these days. The trick is pretty slick, too. Thanks!

I have a slight tremor in my hand, and when I type I sometimes double tap a key or I hit the wrong one. Unbeknownst to me, on one of the rebuses, I typed I NCH. It took me a good 20 minutes to figure out where I screwed up.

Just how many letters can we cram into one box and still call it fun?

Still working on it, but i'm just piping up to object to 125A. Not all witches are crones; only the old ones are. 

And i must be living in a feminist bubble out here in the Pacific Northwest, but i thought we had reclaimed the word crone from the fairy tales *ages* ago --- yet three dictionaries i just checked online (Merriam-Webster, Webster's New World and Oxford English) say the old pejorative stuff about cantankerous hags. Geesh.

I had a great time figuring this one out.  I had a few rebuses, noticed they were types of worms, had the WORMHOLE hint, but couldn't really figure where the post-rebus endings came from, especially when some weren't even real words.  It was only after I found a duplicate rebus and I noticed that its colors were the same, that it all clicked!  Super fun then spending a few minutes worming away to fill in seemingly non-sensical terms like ARACHTER and RISTIAN to get a head start on the rest of the puzzle.

We had family over tonight, and I was asked to set up the charcoal grill at around 5:50, so I knew that if I played it right, I could start the puzzle at 6:00 and hopefully finish before I had to cook the burgers. Since my average Sunday solve time falls within coal-catching time, I figured I'd be able to get it done. The non-theme answers seemed super easy to get (with just a couple of exceptions), but I was halfway through before I got to WORMHOLES, which gave the game away. It did take me about 5 minutes longer than average, but once the wormholes fell into place, it was smooth sailing, and I had to go cook. I did get hung up for a minute or two at SHAKA (seen before but still not familiar with it in that context) , and a random typo that I can't recall anymore. But I did get it done before going back to really take in what was happening. And then it occurred to me: The WORMHOLEs work on both the across and the down answers! There was a previous WORMHOLE puzzle, on Thurs., July 18, 2004, but there were no rebus squares and it only worked once per clue. (The continuations started with an unchecked square, so there was no crossing of two answers at the WORMHOLE square.) See the completed grid at https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/18/2024 ). But this one had two WORMHOLE entries crossing at every WORMHOLE, and rebuses at those spots. Jaw dropper! More in another post about how I think the comments will run.
A fun puzzle with a very clever theme! Finished quite below my Sunday average once I “got it” about halfway through the puzzle.

Two nights in a row, I have written a lengthy post which somehow closed on me just before I was able to send it, and I have no idea what I pressed to cause this, so I will try again here.

This comment is about how the opinions will run.

So far, most of the comments have been favorable, but most of the experienced solvers solve earlier and finish faster, so there have been only a few people who had bad things to say about what is certainly a different and challenging puzzle.

As the 24-hour period progresses with a challenging puzzle or one with a novel trick, we often see less seasoned solvers come to say that the puzzle was unfair or too hard or even "not a crossword".  I think we will see some of that.

Of course, there will be veteran solvers for whom this puzzle is not to their taste, and some newbies who don't blame the puzzle for their inability to solve it.  But nevertheless, the trend will be more praise on Sat. night, more criticism on Sunday.

I think that if veteran solvers can finish a puzzle and praise it, but others get stuck and frustrated, the constructor has created a great puzzle.  If no one can solve it, or everyone can, not so much.  If I were the constructor of a puzzle that hit this sweet spot, I would have cause to be proud.

This was a very good puzzle.
I really enjoyed this one! Tricky and chewy with enough easy fill to keep the frustration level reasonable. And when the penny dropped it was fun to explore the WORMHOLES. Bravo!
Easily one of the best sundays in a while. Really nice construction, fill, and clueing. Great job
That was a tough one, very enjoyable.

Wow, that was extremely, creatively difficult. “EMUOIL” is a bit questionable and I didn’t love the CATO/CAEN honorary OJ Simpson trial corner. 

But mostly fair otherwise.
Nonsensical.

So impressed with the construction of this puzzle and with how much fun it was to complete. I was over my average, but that's not terribly surprising for a rebus puzzle, especially one with an added twist. 

The discoveries on the way to completion were rewarding. I especially enjoyed figuring out that the wormholes were rebuses with types of worms.
Holy moley! That was dense! Thanks for a great puzzle, Dylan Schiff!
Not feeling it on this one.  Don’t care for the double words on a square.  Passing!!

I found this really entertaining. It did take me 90 minutes to complete, but I enjoyed every minute. The theme had me confused for a long time until I realized I had to work the whole grid. That's what I liked best about this theme -- it covered the entire puzzle.
Very clever puzzle -thank you! Just over my average time and I had a lot of fun!
I really loved solving this puzzle. Just a treat from start to finish. In awe of the construction, and loved the bonus of the rebus words being types of worms. Chef's kiss!

Just wanted to chime in here to thank Mr. Schiff -- this was one of the hardest Sunday puzzles I've ever had to solve but at the same time it was an extremely fair test of my ability. Finishing this one in two hours over my average makes me feel like I've really accomplished something. Thank you and well done.
And of course, I was so excited I substituted "hours" for "minutes" in my first post. It took me 33 minutes to finish this, which is two minutes over my average and I loved it.

Appropriate that the RICEAR(ONI) clue EARwormed me...!

Loved this puzzle. ATE it right up. I predict complaints (rebus and also funky entries) but I'm pretty sure any puzzle will generate some complaints regardless.
I can't stop thinking about EMUOIL
That was a lot of fun!

This puzzle was on another level! Absolutely stellar construction and just so much fun to solve! I was at the 50% completion point when I finally figured out the trick and got the hugest grin. 😁 Told my husband to pause his show so I could show him the trick. We were both suitably impressed. Chef’s kiss on this one, Dylan. Well done 👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼

Very slow solve. 

ROOTLE? Really? I think not.

I hate all the clues that need two words like SETSAT or NEEDTO.
Any complaints I had about this puzzle were on me and entirely of the annoyed-until-solved variety. This puzzle is ingenious. Kudos to the constructor!

This was a constructor’s tour de force. I can only begin to imagine how much time this must have taken to put together.  The only downside was that it became relatively easy to solve, but that was probably an inevitable byproduct of the theme itself. One of the most creative Sunday puzzles I have ever completed.
This was so much fun to solve!
It appears that the rules of crossword puzzles are not universal - one letter per square and solutions that relate in someway, any way, to the clue. whosinchristian - hilarious, but c’mon.
Gonna have a LOT of pushback from ME if he thinks TYPEWRITERS are obsolete, I can tell you that, 😉‼️
I loved this one! Very smooth and a nice moment of discovery!
Most enjoyable Sunday solve in a while! Loved every single one of the 65 minutes it took me to finish!

Wow!!! What a puzzle!!

I cottoned (or flaxed?) to the theme when I got the revealer, but still took me a while to see how the wormholes worked. They were rebuses? That were different types of worms? And they worked both across AND down??!? Unbelievable.  Well done, Mr. Schiff. 

Took me nearly an hour, but how satisfying was that to complete? It also happened to be the five-year anniversary of the start of my streak. Quite a suitably challenging puzzle to finish a five-year run with. Thank you again, Dylan.

This puzzle is too hard for me.  I finished all of the puzzle except for the worm holes and came to the column for enlightenment.  Went back and entered the worms, saw what happened, but the puzzle still isn't done.  I'll give it another go in a while.  but I'm feeling too defeated right now to do that.  

I see by comments here that people are blown away by how ingenious the construction is, and I see that it is, but either I've got it wrong or I have a mistake somewhere not associated with the holes.  

Later.

I solve the NYT crossword puzzles on my phone. When I had about 15 clues left I looked at the solving help. I was very frustrated to learn that there were colored circles to guide the way and without them the puzzle couldn’t be solved. I think the puzzle editors should warn  people that solving a particular puzzle is not possible on their phones. I also feel you should provide an alternate puzzle. After all, I am paying a fee to access the puzzles.
The best Sunday puzzles are the ones that make you smile when you realize the theme. This puzzle gave me a big smile. Well done!

I was beginning to think my streak of nearly 5 years was about to end.  I grasped the concept pretty quickly and I could see 33 Down and its mate at 85 Down were the problems.  It finally dawned on me but this puzzle took  me double the amount of time  I usually need.  These cutesy puzzles are going to get me someday, but not today.
Great Puzzle! Had to check the answer key to see I had the wrong letter in the first space in 106 down/across, so I sadly won’t complete/get credit for the puzzle. 😔

super fun! it was challenging until we figured out what was going on. my son and i were tricked by the fact that rice-a-roni fit at 97A. but then we got to 115A and we were sure it had to be macbookair. and then it all started to come together. the layers involved in this puzzle are incredible. what an achievement!
To "gah," I say bah, humbug.

You don't have to be Stephen Hawking to solve this puzzle -- just Dylan Schiff to create it.

Out of this world.

This one was certainly one that took me in multiple directions, but not with any direct connection. I was STYMIED for a while until I realized that there were three sets of two colored dots each, and figured that the similar colors might just have something important for the solve, and the WORMHOLE answer confirmed that.

I had noticed the space shortage, and figured that there would be rebuses, so I had left the colored squares blank as I solved. After a little more examination, I figured out that the rebuses were specific to a color, and that gave me the push that I needed to get the correct terms into the colored spaces.

Fun puzzle, and ingenious construction. Thanks, Dylan.
Fun! Loved the three kinds of worms! 🪱

Started out really annoyed with this puzzle and kinda getting there was likely a rebus in the special squares, but none of what came after the rebus made any sense. Even after getting the revealer, I was confused. Then it clicked. Brilliant puzzle. That I ultimately did enjoy. :)
Wow. Just…WOW. Brilliant puzzle.

Loved this, a real feat of construction and mercifully free of NBA/NFL/NHL etc clues!
I managed to work around the coloured squares until I got the revealer and the theme clicked, from there it was a doubly-satisfying solve.
Awesome work, thanks Dylan!
Huh.  Four of the answers went in one EAR and out the other.
Wow. That was pretty wild. Very cool. I’m still spinning…

Quite the puzzle. 

I got tired and gave up trying to figure which wormhole went with which. It probably would have helped if I'd realized that the colors were matched up.  Oh well, at least I knew that Outkast was a RAPDUO. 

Some of the answers were fun to read without using the wormhole, like ESCAPEARONI and RICEARTIST. 

RICE ARTISTs actually exist. Some use rice to make mosaics or sculptures.  Some carve onto grains of rice or carve things out of grains of rice.

Wow!  What a tight theme and great fill today. Thanks, Dylan!

Almost all dictionary fill.  Limited brand names. Nicely done.
I loved the trick, but man there was a lot of TREACLE in this grid. Maybe that was the tradeoff that had to be made to get the wormholes to work. Still… WATERGAS? ICEIN? EMUOIL? AONE? PEDALER?
My review at Diary of a Crossword Fiend: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/05/24/sunday-may-25-2025/#ny
Loved it! Like Caitlin, I was half done and didn’t get it until I got the wormhole… and didn’t get the relation to the ear, book, etc and worm till i read the column. But I enjoyed it alot. Thanks!

This is the first rebus on a Sunday puzzle that I’ve been able to cotton onto myself. Finished in under a half hour, no hints, clues, or help whatsoever. 
Gonna bask in this for a while. 
Very clever puzzle!
A worm is not a bug.
More annoying than fun.

GAH! I loved this puzzle. Thank you, Dylan, for this wild ride through space and time. There was a regular Wordplay commenter (don't remember their handle, but i'm sure some of you do) who used to encourage us to take a moment to look at the grid before we dive in. I've been so grateful for that advice, and today it served me well: i noticed six circles in colored pairs. When the wormhole theme dawned about halfway through, it was a quick jump back to those pairs. (With help from past Star Trek viewings, as i'm no astrophysicist.)

The construction was genius. As another poster said, solving took us all over the grid. And it took us all through the culture, from Frank CAPRA to OUTKAST, from RICE-A-RONI to TREACLE. Speaking of treacle, did anyone else notice a fair bit of British English here? It was like a lovely wormhole across the pond.

Last, thank you too, Caitlin, for the tip that the three wormhole terms are kinds of worm! It just keeps getting... bigger...
I was saved by RICEARONI.  Being absolutely sure of that answer cracked open the wormhole detail for me.
Caitlin, also, thank you for that Magritte painting. Never seen that one! It is so... delightfully... wormy. And weird as all get-out.

When I first began xwording it never occurred to me that the puzzles could teach me loads about myself.
When I grok a rebus theme I am usually wont to think:  How devilishly clever are we, the puzzle builder and I!
And when I don't I incline to pout and declare:  How dopey and maudlin this meager effort from the puzzler and how rightly affronted am I!
I no longer can discern clearly where the puzzle characteristics end and mine begin.
Are there any famous rice artists?

What an amazing puzzle. I was [HOOK]ed from the start. It took me a while to catch on, but the solve was worth every second.

Even the rebus-haters seem to like this one! (Or, at least, admire it.) My favorite of the wormhole phrases: “stayingINCHild”, which is easy to do with a puzzle this fun.

I’m not sure I’ve encountered ROOTLE before, but now that I have, I plan to use it at every opportunity. It’s a great word.
This was a fun puzzle that challenged my thinking. And my time was 15 minutes slower than my average. It must have been a tough one. More coffee please.
Amazing!  Also, evil.

Wooooow. What a puzzle. Absolutely splendid theme!! I can’t even comprehend how insanely difficult it is to create something like this. 

Wickedly clever, pleasantly difficult. Needed a few lookups to get through this but they were all more than fair in both clueing and crossing! There were just a couple of things well above my pay grade lol but am always happy to learn, especially when it’s a puzzle as brilliant as this one!

This was a superb puzzle, imo.
But how pantheonic would it have been had the non-wormhole straighton reads made some relevant sense, or at least been comprehensible notions?
BRAIN CHARACTER?
OPEN BOOK AIR?
ESCAPEARONI?

Etc.

I mean...not complaining here.
Not a bit.
Loved the puzzle.
I don't have the beginning of the wherewithal to design a puzzle like this.

But just imagine...

After complaining about themeless Sundays a couple of weeks ago, it only feels right to come back to say what a joy this one was. I love, love, love it when you go through your first and even second pass thinking, hmm, something isn’t right here, and then you have that aha moment and it all clicks into place! So clever and so fun. Great way to start a Sunday 🟧🟨🟩🟦🟥
Wow!  “Travel Bug” is clever, intricate, humorous and entertaining.  Also, educational.  Cheers and applause, Mr. Schiff.

Whew! Took me about 50% longer than usual, and totally worth it. 

My first thought looking at the grid was, "Ooh, pretty colors. This is going to be fun!" And it was.

Got very confused by 28A because OPENBOOK fit in the available squares and made sense in its own, so that had me thinking in all kinds of wrong directions. That prevented me from grokking the rebuses for way longer than I'd like to admit. But once I figured them out, wow! Just wow! Beautiful how they work both across and down. 

It wasn't until I read the column that I learned that the rebuses were also types of worms. I wish I'd taken the time to notice it myself.

COBB salad makes me think of Tim Gunn. Around 2010 or so, I won lunch with Tim Gunn while attending a conference for women bloggers in NYC. He told me his favorite salad was Cobb and that I had a "perfect hour-glass figure." He was as nice and kind in person as you would imagine if you've watched Project Runway.
Ow. That was a hard one. AREA RUG had me tripped up for a long time
I did not like this puzzle, it was so frustrating it wasn't even any fun.

I'm following my own advice and skipping the Sunday NYT puzzle. In stead, I did the Saturday Washington Post one. I found it very hard and was unable to solve it without reveals (so much trivia...). Having completed and checked the WP grid I don't understand why 'Negative post?' solves to PRE. Could somebody please explain?

It seems to me this puzzle could have gotten very hard if not for RICEARONI, ESCAPEARISTS, PREBOOKING, and OPENBOOKTEST, which gave me plenty to work with on the theme.  I really liked that the theme worked both across and down, and a lot of the long stuff was good.  What I liked less was that having words "inside" the worm holes doesn't seem to me to make sense to with the theme (oblique Deep Space Nine reference notwithstanding). Also, the title: worms and bugs--not the same thing.

Too tough for me, but that’s my problem, not the puzzles. The non-rebus clues were pretty straightforward and clearly the coloured dots were rebi. But that’s where I hit the wall. An OMG impressive build.  For one, the colored wormhole pairs are symmetrical, which means that not only must the theme answer pairs have the same number of letters, but the wormholes have to fall in a certain square of those answers.  Standing-O, Dylan, for coming up with this theme answer set.

There have been wormhole-type themes in puzzles before, but I believe today’s puzzle is the first where the wormholes work horizontally and vertically, rather than just one direction.  That's not only incredibly impressive, but envelope-pushing as well.

Most importantly, how was the solve?  Mine was like a rollercoaster ride, starting with a big what’s-going-on hill to climb, then a eureka moment, followed by a swoosh to the finish.  

That is, the grind of cracking a thorny riddle – just what my brain adores – followed by the thrill of streaking downhill. Complete gratification.

Finally, ROOTLE!  ROOTLE!  A joy-sparking word if ever there was one.  It’s my earWORM for the day.

As one who sometimes struggles to "get it," I'd like to suggest a little more compassion for the unfairly labeled "haters" here.  Those of you who are so pleased with the constructor, the constructor, and the cleverness of the puzzle might just be pleased for the simple fact that you got it; whether you lucked into it, figured it out, or came to solve the puzzle in some other way, the fact remains that you're (deservedly) proud of yourselves and pleased.  Good for you.  Really.
But you might have a little more compassion for those of us who come here to enjoy some time on a Sunday and don't get it.  We work at it, we struggle with it, and it's increasingly frustrating.  Instead of enjoyment and entertainment, we get frustrated, upset, and don't have a good time.  And some post things they don't mean.  That doesn't make them/us "haters"--a word I think is unfair.
We are not all equally smart, equally clever, equally wise, or equally good at this game.  But we ALL come here for enjoyment.  Those of you who are smart or clever enough to solve the puzzle are pleased.  Rightly so.  But those of us who keep struggling and struggling get understandably frustrated.  None of us are at our best when we're frustrated.    But instead of calling us "haters," you might remember that there was (likely) a time when you struggled too.  When you couldn't solve the puzzle.  And have a little compassion.
That doesn't excuse the nasty, uncalled-for language but a little understanding might help.

When I first started the puzzle, I quickly learned to stay away from the colored squares.  There was clearly something amiss there, and I would have to wait a while until things became clearer. 
When I solved the revealer, I guessed how things would work out: going in one of the pair and out the other, but it wasn't until a bit later that I saw that one would need to put rebuses into the colored circles. 
Since I was working the puzzle from the top down, there was the frustration of not having much to work with with the "exit holes" on the bottom, and it took a little bit longer to see that the colored pairs would have the same rebus in each.
And it wasn't until the whole puzzle was finished that I could look back at the solve and see the WORM-connection in all of the rebuses.

Wow!  So many a-ha moments  in one puzzle, and then the final perusal to think about the genius involved in its construction!
Hats off to you, Dylan Schiff.  This is clearly a great puzzle!

I wish that Rebus squares did not accept just the first letter of the rebus as I then have to spend a lot of time subsequently inserting the rebus in my head (especially a long one), when I realize the they are there.

I'm a daily solver and generally have fun solving.  I'm more of a word person than a visual person, so I've had to learn to look at the grid.  Here, the grid, together with the puzzle title (Travel Bug) were helpful clues.  I've also learned to like -- or at least note hate -- rebuses, so I caught on to that pretty early in my solve.  Even so, the puzzle was frustrating until I got the "wormhole" revealer.  

All that said, though, I didn't enjoy this puzzle -- not because it was too hard or because I'm a "hater".  (Can we please not call names?)  This puzzIe was just not my jam.   I prefer wordplay in the form of puns or riffs on famous quotations or themes related to history or pop culture.  At least it was interesting to learn that Oprah gave eulogies for Toni Morrison and Rosa Parks -- I'll have to look those up.  Also, love that Barb and Star made it into the NYT crossword!

Absolutely love a Sunday exercise of this type - filling in the non-themers as best I can, looking quite blindly at the circles, and then getting not just one but two aha moments: first the worms in the holes and second what they did to the back half of each entry. What a delight. 

As I was tapping over towards the comments to share this observation, I found myself wondering how many folks were going to be here complaining that the puzzle was "too _______ by half." Usually it's "clever," of course, but I think here we have also a "cutesy" or two (what makes a puzzle cutesy vs clever I'm not sure) and I imagine some other options as well were I to look over all 400 and something comments more closely. Who decided that this is the thing to say when what you really mean is you didn't like how difficult it was, and why is it always by half? I'm at a loss. I personally find the description overused by three-quarters at least. 

In any case: thank you to Mr. Schiff for the fun and satisfying solve, and happy Sunday to you all.

My Dad bought an electric portable Smith Corona for his dental office in late 1950's.  When I graduated from high school he gave it to me to take to college. @Jltpaint Why is ROOTLE not fair? Because you don't know it? It's a real word. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rootle ROOTLE is an example of a frequentative verb, one based on a simpler one but with a suffix (-le and -er being two of the most common) that suggests a repetitive or longer action; to ROOTLE is to root around on the ground habitually or for a long period of time. Here are some other frequentative verbs, along with the (pardon the expression) root word they come from: blabber (from blab), crackle (crack), flitter (flit), flutter (float), glimmer (gleam), sniffle (sniff). Here's a more complete list: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequentative

@Regine

I always thought the phrase "too clever by half" was a Scottish one, until I started coming here.
In my part of the world it designates a level of cleverness that exceeds savviness, leading to counterproductive results. It's uttered with a weary headshake.

So (in the usage I'm familiar with, and have uttered myself) it means "I actually completely understand the cleverness here, but I think it hasn't been thought through properly."

So its meaning, in my experience, is almost the reverse of the one you invoke here. Interesting how perceptions, and usages, can differ so strongly.

@Oikofuge thank you for sharing this! I absolutely think the intent of those using the phrase here is to suggest what you say, as though somehow the puzzle was overdone, but given the context in which it's so often uttered, to me it instead shouts "there was a hard trick here and I didn't cotton to it, so I'll complain that the fault was with the puzzle." It reminds me of someone coming to a cocktail party dressed in jeans and a t-shirt accusing the other guests of being overdressed - the difficulty never with the complainer, only with that which they complain about. 

Alas. I appreciate your thoughts. Language really is interesting, isn't it?
